slides.title: i Review: Role based Security in PolicyCenter
slides.originalNotes:
Review: Role based Security in PolicyCenter
Security in PolicyCenter makes the application flexible, robust, and keep your information protected. The PolicyCenter default application contains a set of roles that perform the policy tasks in most organizations. In order to perform these tasks, a user must be assigned a role with the appropriate permissions- Typically, in the base configuration, the Superuser role is granted all permissions and is responsible for granting permissions to other roles. Once the roles are configured, then each PolicyCenter user is assigned a specific role that relates to the tasks to be performed

Note: Although in the base configuration, Superuser has all permissions, but that could change if a customer adds custom permissions. Also, Superuser is configured in the base product as the role that would grant permissions to other roles, but a customer could configure any role to do that.

slides.originalNotes:
System permissions
In the example, the system permissions have been arranged in columns based on the thing the permission pertains to- The second column has only two permissions because you cannot own a group. System permissions are often referred to simply as "permissions“

The entire list of system permissions can be seen in the Security Dictionary.

slides.title: i Roles
slides.originalNotes:
Roles
There are no absolute rules regarding how the permission/role structure must be built to accommodate users with varying levels of access- For example, if
underwriters should be able to do everything an underwriter assistant can do as well as some underwriter-only tasks, then:
You could create the Underwriter role so it has all the permissions of the Underwriter Assistant role plus the additional permissions. Underwriter Assistant
users get just the Underwriter assistant role- Underwriter users get just the Underwriter role.
You could create the Under writer role so it has only the additional permissions that Underwriter Assistants do not get. Underwriter Assistants users get just the Underwriter Assistants role- Underwriter gets both the Underwriter Assistant and the Underwriter role.
Roles have permissions that map to a job function- For example, the producer role contains the set of permissions appropriate for someone who is a producer This role might have the create submissions or edit accounts permissions, but it would not have the create users or even issue submissions permissions. Similarly, a producer clerical role might have only create submissions and not edit accounts- You can have one or more roles (you must have at least one).You are granted all the permissions that are contained in any of the roles that are assigned- Roles provide the basic security that governs which actions you can take within PolicyCenter

i Review: Security Dictionary G

Security Dictionary is a series of HTML pages that document the permissions and
roles in your application
• Located at: <server directory>\build\dictionary\security\index.html

« When you add or edit permissions or roles, you can regenerate the information in these
sections to reflect the changes

* The dictionary has four main sections

slides.title: i Review: Security Dictionary main sections
slides.originalNotes:
Review: Security Dictionary main sections
An application permission key is a set of one or more system permissions.
PolicyCenter defines application permission keys internally as a method for improving system performance. For example, the Account edit permission key represents the system permissions for editing an account, and Account reopen tore open a withdrawn account Application permission keys appear in the files used to specify the user interface, so it is important for users to know what they are- However, you cannot create or modify application permission keys –

The Application Permission Keys section of the security dictionary lists each application permission key, the set of system permissions it contains, and the pages and elements in the user interface that reference the application permission key.

The Pages section of the security dictionary lists each page in the user interface and the permissions needed to view or edit that page (if any). You can click on any of the permissions listed in the right pane, and it takes you to the list of pages that show the relevant permission set.

The System permissions are permissions defined in the System Permission Type type list- Permissions that appear grayed are internal and cannot be modified.
The System permission section of the security dictionary lists each system permission and the roles that contains the system permission, and the pages and elements in the user interface that reference the system permission.

The Roles section of the security dictionary listseach role and the permissions it contains.
Keep in mind that the security dictionary is a series of static HTML pages. If changes are made to the permissions in a given role, the security dictionary must be regenerated to reflect those changes. Users can update the security dictionary through a command-line utility tool called" regen-dictionaryu which is covered in detail in the Configuration Fundamentals course-

slides.title: i Creating System permissions
slides.originalNotes:
Creating System permissions
Permission keys should be all defined in lowercase. Donot combine multiple actions in a permissiom For example, rather than creating a permission to modify an account, create individual permissions for each individual action that will be evaluated per permission. Create permission to edit account, delete account, create new account and so om

 The code of the permission is also referred to as the permission key.

Users must regenerate dictionaries to see new permissions listed within security dictionary- The command is gwb gendictionary

i Creating System permissions

« System permissions are defined in the SystemPermissionType typelist
* Permissions that appear grayed are internal and cannot be modified
« Add typecodes in SystemPermissionType to create new system permissions
* Permission codes should be all lowercase without white spaces
* Specify one permission per action
« Name permission codes as a verb for the entity name and action
• Permission code: [entity][action] — can be interchanged
•« Examples:
* accountcreate: Permission to create an account
* bindsubmission: Permission to bind a submission

* viewsensnote: Permission to view sensitive notes

slides.title: i The perm namespace
slides.originalNotes:
The perm namespace
perm is a built-in Guidewire package that is always in scope, which means you do not need to use fully- qualified type names or the uses operator for it. There are some other built-in packages such as entity, or gw.lang., or productmodel.- Studio prevents you from creating custom packages with any of these names. For instance, if you try to create a package called soap, Studio displays a message in red text that states "Reserved Package“

The application permission key is defined in the SecurityConfig.xm17 which will be discussed more in the next section.

slides.title: i Static and object-based permissions
slides.originalNotes:
Static and object-based permissions
In general, when you want to create any new object or entity the object does not already exist then nothing needs to be passed as parameter and those permissions are called static permissions.

To modify or manage an object, the specific object has to be passed in as an argument. Those permissions are called object-based permissions. In the base configuration, some static permissions are used in an object-based context, but the object passed in is null-

slides.title: i Static permissions on entities
slides.originalNotes:
Static permissions on entities
Generally, create must always be a static permission, since no object is available at the time that the permission is checked. Once the object is created, permissions to view, edit or delete the object would be of type object- based since an object to view or modify would have to be passed as a parameter for the particular action.
Static permissions on entities are defined in the security-config-xml. They are discussed in detail later in the supplemental configuration course.
Example.
The StaticHandler (entity/permKey/Syst emPermType = Account/create/acco untcreate) is defined in security-config.xml
APK "Account create" is listed under Application Permission Keys in security dictionary
The attribute available = perm Account. Create is set for the New Account menu in Tab BAr.pcf
Since the user aapple gate has the permission to create a new account, the menu to create New Account is availableto her- The user aauditor does not have the permission to create a new account and so he does not have the menu available-
